Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, DCPC maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
DCPC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
DCPC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment include pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at DCPC to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

4. Five-year Accident History [40 CFR Part 68.42]

DCPC has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases at all its facilities nation wide. There have been one small accidental release (16 lbs) at this DCPC facility that resulted in evaporating liquid freeze burns to one onsite employee.

5. Emergency Response Plan [ERP] [40 CFR Part 68.95]

Pursuant to the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR Part 68.95, DCPC has a written ERP to address accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all the applicable aspects of emergency response including evacuation, adequate first aid and medical treatment and notification of local emergency response agencies.

The ERP has been coordinated and verified with the Beaumont and China, TX Fire Departments.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79 and 29 CFR 1910.119]
DCPC conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the USEPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
DCPC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
DCPC believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, DCPC employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87]
DCPC occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. DCPC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. DIVERSIFIED CPC INTERNATIONAL INC.
BEAUMONT, TX (new facility starting up in November 2020)
RMP - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Diversified CPC International, Inc. [DCPC] is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that encompasses design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training. Robust engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

2. Regulated Substances Handled

The Beaumont facility will initially have 1 regulated substance, Propane, at the beginning of operations, with Butane expected to be added in the future. Isopentane (2-Methylbutane) was added in November 2021. At the facility, these products are offloaded from rail cars into tank trucks and transported to the customer. The maximum inventory represents ~30 railcars of product, assuming the contents may be either propane, butane, isopentane, or some combination of each product.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

DCPC has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA 58 Standards and API 2510. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
DCPC maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.
